messageBody:
Erik Felker wrote:
>
>
> I am just getting my toes wet in Quickscript, which I find very
> interesting. I am especially interested at the moment in the fact
> that it is a writing system for English that allows people to write as
> they speak. In the USA, for example, we have regional accents that
> essentially disappear when we write English, but which are apparent
> when we speak/listen; Quickscript allows those differences to appear
> naturally in writing if they are desired. I can also see that
> Quickscript could be very useful to someone who is studying English as
> a foreign language.
>

Hi Erik,

Good luck in your pursuit of Quikscript (QS). I just picked up QS about
a month ago. You can gain relative proficiency relatively quickly. For
instance, I can read the news in QS, but I do so very haltingly. I don't
now how long it takes before one can gain close to the same
proficiency one has reading orthodox English, what we call traditional
orthography, or TO.

At the risk of sparking another debate, I feel I should correct the
misconception you have about QS, the same misconception I had when I
first picked up QS. QS does not represent spoken speech, or phonETic
English. Instead, it represents ponEMic English. You can think of the
difference by thinking of the Spanish written language. Spanish is
written as it is pronounced (more or less); but if someone from Spain
were to read something written by something written by someone in
Mexico, he could not hear the accent. Spanish is phonemic, not phonetic.

In contrast, you can think of the novel Huck Finn as phonetic. The
accent of each speaker comes through. If QS were phonetic, think of how
hard it would be to communicate. It is hard enough reading Huck Finn,
but then consider that you had to read a complicated article written in
the same manner, and on top of that, written in Australian dialect,
which for us Americans is very difficult to understand. It might take
you an hour just to read a page. Not only is it not desirable to have QS
represent all accents, it is somewhat impossible. QS has 40 letters. If
we wanted to represents accents, it would need many more letters to
represent the vowels of Australia, as well as some of the dialects in
Ireland and Britain, just to mention a few cases.

Read designed QS not to emphasize accents, but to flatten them out. Of
course, some of one's accent will come through in QS. For example, I
don't distinguish between "beer" and "bear" in my speech, so it is
entirely possible that someone reading a letter written by me in QS
would hear some of my Boston accent. But by in large my accent won't
come through. QS dictates that I pronounce my r's, so the most
distinguishing feature of the Boston accent will be lost.

I hope my explanation helps. I hesitated to write this email, but when I
saw you wrote your second email again thinking how QS represents spoken
speech, I though it best to do so. To the group, I hope I have
represented QS. I had to gloss over some of the complexities we have
discussed, but at the same time my misunderstanding that QS was phonemic
proved a stumbling block when I first picked it up.

Paul
